ref: 10250 mūˊla (mūˊra -- AV.) n. ʻ root ʼ RV., mūlaka -- ʻ arising from ʼ MBh., m.n. ʻ radish ʼ Mn., mūlikā -- f. ʻ root used in magic ʼ Pañcat. 2. *mūḍa -- . [Despite early occurrence and proposed connexion with Gk. mw=lu (IEW 750), variation of -- l/r -- ~ -- ḍ -- supports non -- Aryan, perh. Drav., origin: cf. Tam. muḷā, muḷḷaṅki ʻ radish ʼ &c., DED 4105. Prob. only chance resemblance with L. and Bi. forms of MIA. muḍḍha -- < mūrdhán -- with meaning of ʻ root ʼ]
Pa. mūla -- n. ʻ root ʼ, ˚aka -- n. ʻ root, bulb, radish ʼ;

lang: Aśokan, i.e. the language of the Inscriptions of Aśoka
Language of `Kharoṣṭhī Inscriptions discovered by Sir Aurel Stein in Chinese Turkestan' edited by A. M. Boyer, E. J. Rapson, and E. Senart

ref: Pk. mūla -- n. ʻ root, proximity ʼ, mūlaya -- n. ʻ radish ʼ, mūligā -- f. ʻ a partic. drug ʼ;
